thread.title: Researchers of rare genetic disorders in children mark milestone

title: Researchers of rare genetic disorders in children mark milestone
text:
Gene sequencing researchers mark milestone detecting rare genetic disorders in children Posted February 18, 2017 14:21:14 Map: Melbourne 3000 
Genomic sequencing technology introduced to Melbourne two years ago has vastly improved the ability to identify rare genetic disorders in children, experts say. 
The Murdoch Children's Research Institute and Melbourne Genomics pioneered the program and are today marking their 100th successful detection. 
Clinical geneticist Dr Sue White said each detection allowed a child to receive the correct treatment for their condition. 
"It's an incredibly powerful test in kids with undiagnosed syndromes," she said. 
She said the test allowed patients to stop ineffective treatments or start early intervention for future health issues. 
Dr White said over the two years, she and her fellow researchers had become "quicker and better" at testing, and the team had been able to diagnose five times as many children, at a quarter of the cost. 
The method involves a blood sample taken from the child and the DNA extracted from the blood. 
All of the genes in that DNA are mapped through genomic sequencing, giving researchers a comprehensive picture of a child's genetic information. 
"We generate huge amounts of data and then we use what is know about that child's problem to look for DNA change in genes known to cause that pattern of problems," she said. 'We were just searching the internet, looking for signs' 
Nelle Hookins, 2, is one of the children who has been through the test which determined that she had Cohen syndrome, which affects mental and physical development. 
Until her diagnosis, her parents had spent a frustrating 18 months dealing with specialist after specialist. She was "gravely ill" and had been in hospital 11 times. 
"It was just a really dark period for us where everything was on the table. We were just searching the internet, looking for signs of what it might be," her mother Amanda Hookins said. 
"It was a very traumatic time, I would say and there's a sort of a fear, lots of anxiety, the unknown is enormous because there's so many possibilities out there it's overwhelming." 
Ms Hookins said doctors at the Royal Children's Hospital suggested Nelle join the research project. 
"It brings a kind of peace to know that you don't have to search any more or that you don't have to wonder. Essentially the mystery is solved," she said. 
Genomic sequencing was not possible when Associate Professor White first started out 20 years ago, and was talking to parents about their child. 
"I know your child has something genetic, but I have no way of finding out what that condition is," she had to tell parents back then. 
"That's why this is so revolutionary for our area of work because we can now personalised that child's care." 
Rare conditions affect one in 12 Australians, many of whom are never diagnosed. 
"It's certainly a test we'd like to be able to offer every undiagnosed child with a presumed genetic condition," Ms Hookins said. 
"We're still fighting battles to get that testing funded."
